critique: The document is an approval of a Code of Fair Competition for the Precious Jewelry Producing Industry by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933, under the National Industrial Recovery Act. It reflects a strong interventionist approach by the federal government in regulating industry during the Great Depression. The code aims to establish fair competition, which suggests an effort to stabilize the industry and protect workers. The temporary stay on overtime pay for manufacturers and distributors of jewelry for educational institutions indicates a consideration for the specific needs of different sectors within the industry.
